statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the tangent to the curve $y = \sqrt{3x - 2}$ which is parallel to the line $4x-2y +5 =0$. %

step.context: %text For a tangent to $y=\sqrt{3x-2}$ to be parallel to $4x-2y+5 = 0$, which of the following must be true? %
step.reason:
%text For two lines to be parallel, \underline\text{their slopes must be equal}.
% \begin{align} \text{Now, }4x-2y + 5 &= 0\implies y = 2x + \frac{5}{2} \\ \therefore \text{Slope} &= \underbrace{m = 2}_{\text{Line's slope}} \\ \text{and }\frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3x-2}}\frac{d}{dx}(3x-2) \\ &= \underbrace{\frac{3}{2\sqrt{3x-2}}}_{\text{Tangent's slope}} \\ \text{So } \frac{3}{2\sqrt{3x-2}} &= m = 2 \\ \implies \sqrt{3x-2} &= \frac{3}{4} \text{or } x = \frac{41}{48} \end{align}

step.context: %text The graph shows two points A and B - both with $x=\frac{41}{48}$. The required tangent will be at \underline\text{which of the two points}? %
step.reason:
%text First, $y=\sqrt{3x-2}$ \underline\text{is a parabola}. \[ \underbrace{y^2 = 3x-2=3\left(x-\frac{2}{3}\right) = ax'}_{\text{Equation of a parabola}} \]
But there will \underline\text{two points} with $x=\frac{41}{48}$. And these points will be % \begin{align} y^2 &= 3\frac{41}{48} - 2 = \frac{9}{16} \\ \implies y &= \pm\frac{3}{4} \\ \therefore A&=\left(\frac{41}{48},\frac{3}{4}\right)\text{ and } B = \left(\frac{41}{48},-\frac{3}{4}\right) \end{align} %text
However, the required tangent must slope upwards $(m=2)$. And that is possible only \underline\text{at A}.
Hence, point A is the only point we need to consider. %

step.context: %text Given that the \underline\text{required tangent is at point A}, what will be the equation of this tangent? %
